text: All right so Deep Agent can now generate full mobile apes straight from a natural language prompt And this is the moment where things actually change because up until now most of this stuff lived in the web world Websites, dashboards internal tools that music kind of thing Useful, sure but mobile apes are different Mobile is where real products live That's where people actually spend time every day And honestly this is something a lot of people including me personally have been waiting for What Deep Agent is doing here isn't about making development a little faster but actually changing how apes get created in the first place People used to use the term vibe coding for something that was honestly way more primitive than this But this is different And to show you how this really works in practice not just on paper it was tested across several very different ape ideas all generated from scratch using prompts So, one of the first apes generated was a New Year's resolution happy And that might sound simple at first but it's actually a good stress test Tracking habits over time is not trivial You're dealing with recurring behavior progress tracking streak logic summaries and persistence The prompt itself wasn't technical at all It basically said "Create a mobile ape where people can define resolutions attach daily habits to them track progress and see how they're doing over time Also make sure the experience feels motivating not mechanical From there Deep Agent asked a few clarifying questions the kind a product manager might ask How should progress be logged Are habits daily or flexible Should streaks matter How long do resolutions last Once that context was clear the ape was built What came out wasn't a airframe or a concept It was a working mobile happy You can add resolutions define habits under each one log progress day by day and see feedback update as you got And the important part is that this behavior continues across sessions You close the happy come back later and everything is exactly where you left it That tells you a lot about what's happening behind the scenes There's real storage there's structure there's logic keeping track of time progress and consistency None of that was spelled out explicitly music It was inferred from the way the goal was described And if something feels off you just tell it what to tweak and it updates You can even give it visual references If you want it to feel closer to another ape you like you attach screenshots and that style gets folded into the results After that the testing moved into something more grounded and data heavy an expense tracking happy This one involved users logging expenses categorizing them working with multiple currencies setting budgets and reviewing summaries over time Again, the prompt wasn't about implementation It was about behavior how people add expenses how they music review spending what kind

something more grounded and data heavy an expense tracking happy This one involved users logging expenses categorizing them working with multiple currencies setting budgets and reviewing summaries over time Again, the prompt wasn't about implementation It was about behavior how people add expenses how they music review spending what kind AI filled in the rest Now, what's striking here is how much infrastructure quietly appears once the ape is generated There's a backed running on Node.js. There are APIs handling expenses categories music budgets and authentication There's a database you can inspect You can see where data is stored music run queries and even download it And the entire thing was generated using around 320 credits That number is important because if you've played with earlier AI coding tools you know how quickly costs can spiral when you ask them to do anything nontrivial Here, that cost is almost negligible especially on a monthly plan And after the initial build you still have plenty of room to iterated redesign add integrations or expand features From a user's perspective it just feels like a normal well-made expense ape where everything updates as you use it budgets make sense over time and nothing feels hacked together or fake Then the same approach was applied to a fitness tracker The goal here was pretty familiar Users sign in log workouts see daily activity review statistics and track progress over time Once again Deep Agent asked a few questions to clarify expectations then built the happy The result is a mobile fitness ape where workouts can be logged in seconds music daily activity is visible immediately and history accumulates naturally over time And again this didn't burn through credits It took very little to get something functional At this point a pattern becomes obvious The complexity of the ape scales with how much you put into the prompt Keep it simple and you get something lightweight Add more detail and you get something richer The system doesn't force you into one approach Things get more interesting when the test moves away from dashboards and into interactive experiences That's where the mobile game comes in The idea was to build a match three style game something in the spirit of Candy Crush with colorful visuals and engaging mechanics This is where you'd normally expect an AI system to struggle because games involve mealtime state rules progression and feedback loops But that's not what happened because instead it paused and pushed back with the kind of questions a real game designer would ask trying to figure out whether this should be a multilevel experience how scoring should actually matter what kind of mechanics make it engaging and whether players should jump straight in or have progress saved over time Those answers shaped the entire structure of the happy Once they were provided the system built a playable game What came out as a functioning match three game with levels special mechanics score

mechanics make it engaging and whether players should jump straight in or have progress saved over time Those answers shaped the entire structure of the happy Once they were provided the system built a playable game What came out as a functioning match three game with levels special mechanics score like a mobile game you can play it immediately And because it doesn't rely on accounts there's no heavy backed to managed You can just publish music it and let people play This one used more credits which makes sense There's more logic involved But the important thing is that the system wasn't just spitting out code It was reasoning about gamely and implementing rules that feel familiar and coherent Now, the most complex example was a social media style mobile happy loosely inspired by platforms like X, but built specifically for mobile Here the system had to think about user accounts music posting feeds and interaction It walked through what should be included in an initial version and what should music be left for later That kind of scoping is something experienced product teams spend a lot of time on The generated ape includes login profiles posting and a basic feed It's clearly an MVP, and that's intentional You start small see how users respond and iterated Deep Agent makes that iteration cycle extremely fast You don't rebuild from scratch You just describe what's next And real quick what's the one ape idea you'd try to ship that could blow up in 2026? I want to see those ideas in the comments Now, all of this ties directly into another major capability Deep Agent also introduced recently music which is argentic workflows. Automation is going through the same kind of shift that ape development is going through Traditional automation tools force music you to define every step manually If something changes the workflow breaks and you're back fixing logic This AI actually music flips that dynamic and instead of wiring every step you describe the outcome you want The system figures out how to get there builds the workflow, runs it monitors it and adapts when inputs change And this really matters because the moment automation starts touching real work it has to exist inside some structure where you can see what happened control how things move forward connect it to other systems and actually hold it accountable Otherwise, chiton setups collapse quickly and rigid workflows snap as soon as things get messy Deep agent combines both The model reasons through ambiguity and the workflow enforces structure This works especially well for things like invoice processing where formats change constantly and rigid parsers fail It also works for lead enrichment outreach customer support reporting pipelines and content quality control In all of these cases you want intelligence making decisions while a structured system ensures consistency and traceability What makes this powerful is that workflows don't exist in isolation They live in the same environment where you reason about

lead enrichment outreach customer support reporting pipelines and content quality control In all of these cases you want intelligence making decisions while a structured system ensures consistency and traceability What makes this powerful is that workflows don't exist in isolation They live in the same environment where you reason about agents That tight integration is what keeps the system from becoming fragile When you look at mobile ape generation and argentic workflows together the direction is very clear This is about moving away from telling systems exactly how to do things and toward telling them what needs to be done Developers don't disappear in this world Their role shifts upwards They focus on orchestration constraints and edge cases instead of manual implementation And for people who aren't developers the barrier to building real software drops dramatically You don't need to learn syntax You don't need to learn design tools music And you definitely don't need to hire a team just to test an idea You describe the product The system music builds it You refine it You ship All right Drop your take in the comments Subscribe if you want more breakdowns like this Thanks for watching and I'll catch you in the next one
